title: How to Make Salad Croutons

steps.headline: Preheat your oven.
steps.description: Set it to 400ºF (200ºC) and place a rack in the upper middle position.

steps.headline: Choose your bread.
steps.description: A crusty, rustic loaf such as sourdough or ciabatta makes excellent croutons. Sandwich bread will work fine, as long as the slices are thick enough not to fall apart when cut. Roughly six slices' worth of bread makes one large batch, enough for several people. Slightly stale bread crisps faster and more evenly. If using a fresh, dense bread, lower the oven temperature to 350ºF (175ºC) or less to help the bread cook evenly.

steps.headline: Cut or tear the bread into pieces.
steps.description: Aim for cubes about ½ inch (1.25 cm) across. If the pieces are too different in size, they will not bake evenly.

steps.headline: Add salt, pepper, and dried herbs.
steps.description: Put the cubed bread in a large bowl and sprinkle on salt and pepper. Optionally, sprinkle on a generous pinch of dried herbs or spices for extra flavor. Oregano, basil, parsley, and thyme are popular flavors for Italian croutons. Garlic powder is the easiest way to add garlic flavor, since raw garlic will burn in the oven. If you prefer to use raw garlic, infuse its flavor in olive oil instead, then strain out the garlic pieces before using the oil in the next step.

steps.headline: Toss the bread in olive oil or melted butter.
steps.description: This is mainly a question of flavor preference, but be aware that butter will burn faster than oil, potentially creating darker croutons. Whichever option you choose, drizzle on 3 tbsp (45 mL) and toss until the bread is coated.

steps.headline: Put the bread in the oven.
steps.description: Spread out the bread in a single layer on a rimmed baking sheet. Place it in the preheated oven.

steps.headline: Bake until brown, flipping the bread occasionally.
steps.description: The bread is ready once golden-brown and crunchy. This typically takes 8–10 minutes if you used fresh bread, or 6–8 minutes if the bread was already stale. Turn over the bread pieces at least once during cooking, so they crisp evenly. Cooking time can vary by several minutes based on how hot your oven runs, the age of your bread, and on how dark and crunchy you prefer your croutons. Keep an eye on them.

steps.headline: Add fresh herbs or grated Parmesan during cooking.
steps.description: These ingredients are best added after 5 minutes of baking.

steps.headline: Eat or store the croutons once cool.
steps.description: Wait for the croutons to reach room temperature, then store in a plastic bag or other airtight container. Storing them while hot may cause them to become soggy from trapped steam. Eat the croutons within one week, or store excess in the freezer for up to six months.

steps.headline: Cut slightly stale bread into cubes.
steps.description: Fried croutons can end up with a chewy interior if they don't cook all the way through. Minimize this by starting with a loaf that's slightly dried out. Cut or tear the bread into cubes or pieces roughly ½ inch (1.25 cm) across. If all you have is fresh bread, pre-toast the cubes in a 200ºF (90ºC) oven for ten minutes or until dry at the surface. Remove them from the oven and continue to the next step.

steps.headline: Warm butter or olive oil in a large pan.
steps.description: Coat the base of the pan and heat until the butter has melted, or until the olive oil is shimmering. Butter burns at lower temperatures, so it tends to create darker croutons.

steps.headline: Mix in bread cubes.
steps.description: Drop the bread cubes in the oil and mix until well coated. If the bread still looks dry, pour more melted butter or olive oil on top.

steps.headline: Add seasoning.
steps.description: Stir in salt and pepper to taste. Optionally, add dried Italian seasoning, or a sprinkle of grated Parmesan cheese.

steps.headline: Brown on several sides.
steps.description: Fry the croutons over medium heat. Once the bases have browned, turn them to expose another side to the heat. The croutons are ready once they are mostly golden-brown, and smell toasted but not burned. Taste-test as you go if you're not sure whether the croutons are done.

steps.headline: Let cool on a paper towel.
steps.description: Transfer the croutons onto a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil. Leave the croutons to release steam and cool to room temperature before using or storing. Once finished, store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week. Transfer any leftovers to the freezer after that point.

text: Baked Croutons Preheat your oven. Set it to 400ºF (200ºC) and place a rack in the upper middle position. Choose your bread. A crusty, rustic loaf such as sourdough or ciabatta makes excellent croutons. Sandwich bread will work fine, as long as the slices are thick enough not to fall apart when cut. Roughly six slices' worth of bread makes one large batch, enough for several people. Slightly stale bread crisps faster and more evenly. If using a fresh, dense bread, lower the oven temperature to 350ºF (175ºC) or less to help the bread cook evenly. Cut or tear the bread into pieces. Aim for cubes about ½ inch (1.25 cm) across. If the pieces are too different in size, they will not bake evenly. Add salt, pepper, and dried herbs. Put the cubed bread in a large bowl and sprinkle on salt and pepper. Optionally, sprinkle on a generous pinch of dried herbs or spices for extra flavor. Oregano, basil, parsley, and thyme are popular flavors for Italian croutons. Garlic powder is the easiest way to add garlic flavor, since raw garlic will burn in the oven. If you prefer to use raw garlic, infuse its flavor in olive oil instead, then strain out the garlic pieces before using the oil in the next step. Toss the bread in olive oil or melted butter. This is mainly a question of flavor preference, but be aware that butter will burn faster than oil, potentially creating darker croutons. Whichever option you choose, drizzle on 3 tbsp (45 mL) and toss until the bread is coated. Put the bread in the oven. Spread out the bread in a single layer on a rimmed baking sheet. Place it in the preheated oven. Bake until brown, flipping the bread occasionally. The bread is ready once golden-brown and crunchy. This typically takes 8–10 minutes if you used fresh bread, or 6–8 minutes if the bread was already stale. Turn over the bread pieces at least once during cooking, so they crisp evenly. Cooking time can vary by several minutes based on how hot your oven runs, the age of your bread, and on how dark and crunchy you prefer your croutons. Keep an eye on them. Add fresh herbs or grated Parmesan during cooking. These ingredients are best added after 5 minutes of baking. Eat or store the croutons once cool. Wait for the croutons to reach room temperature, then store in a plastic bag or other airtight container. Storing them while hot may cause them to become soggy from trapped steam. Eat the croutons within one week, or store excess in the freezer for up to six months. Fried Croutons Cut slightly stale bread into cubes. Fried croutons can end up with a chewy interior if they don't cook all the way through. Minimize this by starting with a loaf that's slightly dried out. Cut or tear the bread into cubes or pieces roughly ½ inch (1.25 cm) across. If all you have is fresh bread, pre-toast the cubes in a 200ºF (90ºC) oven for ten minutes or until dry at the surface. Remove them from the oven and continue to the next step. Warm butter or olive oil in a large pan. Coat the base of the pan and heat until the butter has melted, or until the olive oil is shimmering. Butter burns at lower temperatures, so it tends to create darker croutons. Mix in bread cubes. Drop the bread cubes in the oil and mix until well coated. If the bread still looks dry, pour more melted butter or olive oil on top. Add seasoning. Stir in salt and pepper to taste. Optionally, add dried Italian seasoning, or a sprinkle of grated Parmesan cheese. Brown on several sides. Fry the croutons over medium heat. Once the bases have browned, turn them to expose another side to the heat. The croutons are ready once they are mostly golden-brown, and smell toasted but not burned. Taste-test as you go if you're not sure whether the croutons are done. Let cool on a paper towel. Transfer the croutons onto a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil. Leave the croutons to release steam and cool to room temperature before using or storing. Once finished, store in an airtight container at room temperature for up to a week. Transfer any leftovers to the freezer after that point.
